nav.div: Seattle Public Schools » Our District » Calendars and News » News » What's New » Coronavirus Update » Grades During School Closure

div.h2: Board Approved District High School Grading Recommendations for Spring Semester 2020
div.p: On Monday, April 20, the Seattle School Board voted to temporarily suspend the grade-marking portion of the district’s high school grading policy to be replaced with the grade marks “A” or “Incomplete” for the duration of the COVID-19 school closure. Read the district's high school grading policy.

To reduce the spread of COVID-19, Seattle Public Schools closed our buildings on Thursday, March 12 and Governor Jay Inslee extended this closure through the remainder of the school year statewide. As a result, Seattle Public Schools, along with many districts across the country, has had to rethink how we provide education remotely for our diverse student population. Regardless of our buildings being closed, learning must continue for our 53,000 scholars.

As a result of the closure, a new Seattle Public Schools grading policy was recommended to the board, which aligns directly with our five-year strategic plan, Seattle Excellence. The new temporary grading policy was developed using the district’s Racial Equity Analysis Tool, including review of student case studies, to ensure an intentional focus on students furthest from educational justice during this significant disruption to our regular lives.

School districts weren’t fully prepared to transition to continuous, remote learning experiences including how we assess student learning. This unprecedented time in public education has provided an opportunity for SPS leadership to closely examine and attend to many systemic inequities. Grading has long been one of the biggest sources of inequities in education because grades may be influenced by factors outside a student’s control, including access to resources and opportunities outside of school. Grades have historically rewarded students with privilege and penalized others. This issue has become even more apparent during this COVID-19 emergency.

A quote many leaders referred back to help shape discussions and decisions came from Milken Foundation-awarded educator, Dr. Manuel Rustin: “How could I really know whether everyone had the tools, space, time, and clarity of mind to engage in my classwork during a global pandemic?” Visit the Milken Family Foundation website to read Dr. Rustin's essay.

Superintendent Denise Juneau recommended to the School Board that high schools use “A” or “Incomplete” as the only grading options for the Spring 2020 semester. After much thought, analysis, and conversation, she concluded that this is the best option for our students in order to meet our overarching goal of ensuring that the extended school closure does not result in harm to students, particularly those furthest away from educational justice. Other options that were discussed included using “credit” or “no credit;” using regular letter grades; keeping the letter grade as of March 10, 2020 with an opportunity only to improve; or let schools and teachers decide.

Many universities and other programs across the country have stated that students will not be penalized for posting credit/no credit transcripts for this semester, but this approach is not universal across all postsecondary institutions. Making “A” the only credit-based grade will ensure students are not harmed as a result of their circumstances or inequitable access to technology and the internet and, as a result, educator instruction. In addition, to ensure students stay engaged, educators will have the option to give “Incompletes” to students who had the ability to engage in learning but did not. Students who receive an “Incomplete” will be able to complete work through summer and fall semesters of 2020 and the transcript will be adjusted at a later date.
The high school grading policy approved by the Seattle School Board is in alignment with OSPI’s Student Learning and Grading Guidance that was released on April 21, 2020.

a.title: go to the strategic plan webpage

div.p: This post was updated to reflect the April 20 School Board vote.
